journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Sampled-data switched control for flexible air-breathing hypersonic vehicles

article-meta.aff: 1Research Institute of Intelligent Control and Systems, Harbin Institute of Technology, China
2Department of Automation, North China Electric Power University, China
3Hypervelocity Impact Research Center, Harbin Institute of Technology, China
4Defense Technology R&T Center, China Aerospace Science and Industry Corporation, China

author-notes.corresp: Xiaoxiang Hu, Xi’an Research Institute of High-Tech, 302 Unit, Hongqing Town, Xi’an 710025, China. Email: huxiaoxiang2008@gmail.com

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue on advanced control of aerospace vehicles

abstract.p: The nonstandard dynamic characteristics of flexible air-breathing hypersonic vehicles along with the aerodynamic effects of hypersonic flight cause the flight control of such vehicles highly challenging. Additionally, the wide range of speed and the varied parameters make the problem more difficult. In this article, the problem of sampled-data switched output tracking control design is addressed for flexible air-breathing hypersonic vehicles. First, the nonlinear longitudinal model of flexible air-breathing hypersonic vehicles is linearized with respect to different regions, and the switched sampled-data guaranteed cost controller design problem is discussed. Using an input delay approach, the switched system with sampling measurements is transformed into a continuous time-delay system. Then, by a Lyapunov approach, the existence condition of such a controller is developed in the form of linear matrix inequalities. A smooth switching condition is also designed simultaneously, and the sampled-data smooth switching controller design problem is cast into a convex optimization problem. The simulation results are reported to show the effectiveness of the proposed control method.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Air-breathing hypersonic vehicles (AHVs) have attracted much attention in recent years for the promising prospects of space exploiture and global reaching capabilities. The payload of AHVs is much bigger than ordinary flight vehicles, and it is much faster in speed. But the interactions between the elastic airframe, the propulsion system, and the structural dynamics of AHVs are very strong,1 and the flight envelope is very big, which makes the parameters to vary quickly.2

The control design of the systems for AHVs is a challenging task because of the high complexity of the equations, strong couplings between propulsive and aerodynamic effects, large flight envelope, and varying parameters.3 In the past few decades, the modeling and control design for AHVs have received considerable attention. Recently, Bolender and Doman4 developed a flexible air-breathing hypersonic vehicle (FAHV) model. For this model, the control design and simulation problems have been reported over the past decade. In Jankovsky et al.5 the authors present two output feedback control methods to control design for the FAHVs models, and in Parker et al.6 a control-oriented model and an example of control design based on approximate feedback liberalization are proposed. Sigthorsson et al.7 deal with the problem of reference output velocity and altitude tracking control for an overactuated longitudinal model. An adaptive sliding mode controller is given in Hu et al.,8 and the fault-tolerant control and guaranteed cost control of this model are studied in Li et al.9,10 Although so many results have been studied, the efficient control strategy for all of the flight envelope and the varied parameters have not been fully investigated.

The nonlinear equations of FAHVs admit a parameter-dependent family of equilibrium solutions or operating conditions. Then, the nonlinear system can be made locally asymptotically stable by a feedback controller. Each equilibrium has a feedback controller and a closed-loop domain of attraction associated with it. For the tracking control problem, it may be impossible to get a good performance just utilizing a single equilibrium point of the system, since the trim condition may be unsuitable for the final equilibrium. Switched control is to design a switched law and switched feedback functions, so that the trajectory of FAHVs can move from a neighborhood of one equilibrium to a neighborhood of another equilibrium and eventually toward the final equilibrium. Switched control has been studied in several articles,11–19 but to the best of our knowledge, there are very few studies addressing on the switched control of FAHVs.

Moreover, most of the previous studies on the controller design of FAHVs are based on the assumption that the states and output of the plant can be measured in real time, and the input can be obtained or produced immediately, so that the designed controller is a continuous-time system. But along with the wide use of digital devices, it is difficult to implement them directly to physical systems. In a real situation, the states and outputs are measured only at sampling instants, and the control input can only be constructed by utilizing the measured states. This means that the continuous-time measurement signal is sampled as a discrete-time signal, and the discrete-time control signal is produced by the controller and converted back into the continuous-time system. To overcome such difficulties, a sampled-data controller design problem for FAHVs is considered here. The sampled-data control problem has been extensively investigated.20,21 An effective way to approach the sampled-data control problem, which models the sampling interval as a time-delayed control inputs for the continuous-time systems, is adopted here. The method has been studied and applied in Fridman et al.22,23 and Suplin et al.24 but there are really very few results on the tracking control of FAHVs.

Based on the above-mentioned observations, this article addresses the problem of switched sampled-data control design problem for the output tracking of FAHVs. First, the flight envelope is divided into several regions, and the complex dynamic characteristics of FAHVs are represented by a switched system. Then, a switched guaranteed cost tracking performance ana-lysis condition and the sampled-data control objective are presented. Using an input delay approach, the closed-loop system becomes a time-delay system, and then by a Lyapunov approach, the existence conditions for desired controllers are formulated in the form of liner matrix inequalities (LMIs), which can be solved by standard numerical algorithms. For getting a better control performance and a smooth control input, a smooth switching condition is also derived for the system. The smooth switched sampled-data controller design is cast into a convex optimization problem subject to LMI constraints. With the obtained controllers, FAHVs can maintain a good performance under sampling and switching. An illustrative example is provided to show the effectiveness and advantage of the proposed control design method. (See Appendix 1 for an explanation of the notation used throughout this article.)

sec.title: Controller design
sec.p:
The closed-loop system in equation (6) involves both continuous and discrete signals, so it is difficult to use the traditional lifting techniques to solve this sampled-data switched control problem. In this section, the problem will be discussed through an input delay approach. The interval between any two sampling instants is assumed to be bounded by

sec.title: Smoothness condition
sec.p: When utilizing the switched controller, the control input may nonsmooth at the switching boundaries. The existence of the input chattering will affect the performance of the system and may cause damage to the actuator. How to derive a smooth switched controller that can make input chattering as small as possible is an important and necessary problem for a practical system.
From the section ‘Controller design’, the controller for each region can be written as

If the difference between
Y ( i )
and
Y ( j )
,
( i , j ∈ F , i ≠ j )
is small, which means that
Y ( i ) ; Y ( j )
, then the control signal over the switching boundary will be smooth. For this case, the following optimization problem is proposed

By minimizing
γ
as much as possible, the requirement
Y ( i ) ; Y ( j )
can be achieved. For the switched sampled-data controller proposed in section “Controller design,” all the connecting rules in all the regions should be considered when designing the smooth switched controller. The condition (17) can be converted into the following LMIs

where

is the total connecting rules in all the regions. Then the problem can be solved numerically. Together with the controller design LMI constraints, the convex optimization problem can be written as follows

sec.p:

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this article, the problem of switched sampled-data guaranteed cost control design has been researched in the context of the longitudinal model of FAHVs. The control design for the FAHVs is high challenging because of the big flight envelope and time-varying parameters. A switched guaranteed cost control objective for FAHVs has been proposed, and the sampled-data control design method has been presented. The switched linearized model has been established around the trim condition of different regions and then the sampled-data control system has been transformed into a continuous-time system with input delay. The existence of such a controller has been analyzed via the Lyapunov functional approach and LMI method. The simulation results have been reported to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed control design method.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p:
The notation used throughout this article is fairly standard. The transpose of the matrix
W
is denoted by
W
T
; the notation
X
>
0
is used to define a symmetric positive-definite matrix and
X < 0
is used to define negative-definite matrix; in symmetric block matrices or complex matrix expressions, we use an “*” to represent a term that is induced by symmetry;
R
n
denotes the n-dimensional Euclidean space and
R
n × m
denotes the set of all
n × m
real matrices;
diag { … }
stands for a block diagonal matrix; and
I
and
0
denote the identity matrix and zero matrix with compatible dimensions, respectively.
